***Parents/Guardians of Kindergarten Students***

We have discovered that there was an error in the setup of some Kindergarten student Google accounts. All Kindergarten Google accounts should end in the number 33, which is their high school graduation year. Kindergarten students who were given a login that ends in "32" need to type in their account log-in with a "33" instead of a "32." The passwords that were shared with you have not changed.

Ken-Ton Google accounts are set up as follows: students last name, followed by the first two letters in their first name, followed by their graduation year. The domain after the "@" symbol is student.ktufsd.org. For example: The Google account for a kindergarten student named Minnie Mouse would be MOUSEMI33@student.ktufsd.org

If you have problems logging in, please email tech_services@ktufsd.org. Thank you!

***Important Message for Parents and Families***

A new program, the Ken-Ton Virtual Learning Academy, is in the process of being developed in order to provide a 100% online/remote learning option for families. You can find the electronic form as well as a detailed FAQ document at www.ktufsd.org/virtual. Deadline is end of the day Friday, August 14. We were also honored to welcome Superintendent Sabatino Cimato, who became the 16th indidividual in the district's 100+ year history to serve as our Superintendent of Schools!

The Buffalo News has published a wonderful Fathers Day column by retired USA Today sports reporter Erik Brady (himself a native of Kenmore) about Kenmore West alumnus Jim Overfield, who is completing a new book on the Buffalo Bisons entitled "The Seasons of Buffalo Baseball."

Jim Overfield, who earned his doctorate at Princeton and is a history professor emeritus at the University of Vermont, is the son of the late Joe Overfield, a very familiar name for Buffalo baseball fans. Joe Overfield attended thousands of Bisons games beginning in 1925 and went on to become the preeminent authority on the subject, culminating with his definitive 1985 book entitled "The 100 Seasons of Buffalo Baseball." He had always intended on updating his book before he passed away in 1999, but his son Jim Overfield is picking up where he left off. "The Seasons of Buffalo Baseball" will be an update and revision of his father's work.

Read Brady's column here:

https://buffalonews.com/2020/06/21/joe-overfield-wrote-the-book-on-buffalo-baseball-his-son-continues-the-story-naturally/

Thank you to all those who voted. More information on the election, propositions, candidates, and more can be found at

Amidst the economic and societal turmoil brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic, a group of people in the Ken-Ton community have come together to form a community-driven rapid response team, called Ken-Ton Cares, to help those struggling with food insecurity. It began as a group on social media and over the past three weeks has evolved into an army of dedicated volunteers confronting the unprecedented challenges brought about by coronavirus.

Since then, the group has grown to include more than 1,800 members who have banded together to collect donations of food supplies, secure volunteers, piece together a fabric of support for people who need help in the community, and distribute food to families in need.

Read the story here to learn more about the group and what to do if you need assistance or want to offer your help:

post_text: On Saturday, March 28, students are invited to take part in a free workshop on flash fiction. The session, entitled Short and Sweet: Reading and Writing Flash Fiction, will take place from 11am to 12pm in the Kenmore Middle School Building (155 Delaware Road), Room 105. This workshop will focus on flash fiction, sometimes called microfiction, sudden fiction, twitterature, postcard fiction, or napkin fiction. Flash fiction challenges writers to tell a complete story within a very compressed space  often in just six to one thousand words. During the one-hour workshop, participants will read a few examples of flash fiction, discuss features of strong flash fiction, and try writing their own. For more information, visit www.ktufsd.org/WritingCenter.

Thanks to the Kenmore West Challenge/Interact Club in partnership with the Kenmore Rotary, thousands of children will soon receive the polio vaccine as part of an international effort to eradicate the virus! Students Sheila Guetti, Amanda Gambino, Hanin Faisal, Andriy Vakolyuk, Kevin Hamilton, Donia Jebara, Angle Mrozik, Anna Puchalski, Skylar Stychalska, Parker Wilby, Sienna DiGiulio, Victoria Nada, Julia Smith, Emily Forney, Anthony Williams and Dominique Eubanks brought the "Purple Pinkie Project" to 4 elementary schools and both middle schools where they painted pinkie fingers purple in exchange for donations which will be matched by the Kenmore Rotary and then tripled by the Gates Foundation.
